children.name: Fit

features.situation: to all HT rolls to stay conscious, avoid death, resist disease, or resist poison

children.notes: Recover FP at twice the normal rate (but not FP spent for spells or psi powers)

features.situation: to rolls for any lengthy mental task you concentrate on to the exclusion of other activities, if the GM feels such focus would be beneficial
to all rolls to notice interruptions while obsessed with a task

modifiers.name: Alternate Benefit
modifiers.notes: Bonus to resist deception involving numbers

features.situation: on any task that requires creativity or invention, including most rolls against Artist skill and all Engineer rolls for new inventions

advantages.name: 3 - Armor (Superscience) - Spend a total of 700 Points from the following:

modifiers.name: Directional
modifiers.notes: @Direction: Back, Right, Left, Top or Underside@

modifiers.name: Tough Skin
modifiers.notes: Effects that just require skin contact or a scratch ignore this DR

modifiers.name: Partial (@Location, 1 level per -1 Per Hit Modifier, Torso is -10% thus level 1@)

children.name: Chip Slots (Modular Abilities)
children.notes: One slot, and each Skill/Advantage Point of Ability costs 2 pts/lvl. For concurrent slots, buy this multiple times.

modifiers.name: Oxygen Storage
modifiers.notes: Can hold breath 25 times as long as normal

modifiers.name: Oxygen Storage
modifiers.notes: Can hold breath 50 times as long as normal

modifiers.name: Oxygen Storage
modifiers.notes: Can hold breath 100 times as long as normal

modifiers.name: Oxygen Storage
modifiers.notes: Can hold breath 200 times as long as normal

modifiers.name: Oxygen Storage
modifiers.notes: Can hold breath 300 times as long as normal

advantages.name: 4 - Pick a total of -25 Points in Disadvantages from the following:

children.name: Bad Sight (Nearsighted)

features.situation: to Vision rolls to spot items more than 1 yd away

children.notes: Double actual distance to the target when calculating the range modifier for ranged attacks

children.name: Code of Honor (Professional)
children.notes: Adhere to the ethics of your profession; always do your job to the best of your ability; support your guild, union, or professional association.

children.name: Overconfidence

features.situation: from young or naive individuals who believe you are as good as you say you are

children.notes: You must make a self-control roll any time the GM feels you show an unreasonable degree of caution. If you fail, you must go ahead as though you were able to handle the situation!

children.name: One Hand

features.situation: on tasks that are possible with one arm but that are usually executed with two

children.notes: You cannot use two-handed weapons, wield two weapons at once (or a weapon and a shield), or perform any task that requires two arms

children.name: One Arm

features.situation: on tasks that are possible with one arm but that are usually executed with two

children.notes: You cannot use two-handed weapons, wield two weapons at once (or a weapon and a shield), or perform any task that requires two arms

children.name: Pacifism: Cannot Harm Innocents
children.notes: You may fight – you may even start fights – but you may only use deadly force on a foe that is attempting to do you serious harm. Capture is not “serious harm” unless you are already under penalty of death or have a Code of Honor that would require suicide if captured. You never intentionally do anything that causes, or even threatens to cause, injury to the uninvolved – particularly if they are “ordinary folks.”

children.name: Pacifism: Self-Defense Only
children.notes: You only fight to defend yourself or those in your care, using only as much force as necessary (no pre-emptive strikes allowed!). You must do your best to discourage others from starting fights.

children.name: Pacifism: Reluctant Killer
children.notes: You are psychologically unprepared to kill people. Whenever you make a deadly attack (e.g., with a knife or a gun) against an obvious person whose face is visible to you, you are at -4 to hit and may not Aim. If you cannot see the foe’s face (due to a mask, darkness, or distance, or because you attacked from behind), the penalty is only -2, save in close combat. You have no penalty to attack a vehicle (even an occupied one), an opponent you do not believe is a person (including things with Horrific or Monstrous appearance), or a target you can’t actually see (e.g., a set of map coordinates or a blip on a radar screen). If you kill a recognizable person, the effect on you is the same as for Pacifism: Cannot Kill. You have no problem with your allies killing; you may even supply ammo, loaded weapons, and encouragement! You just can’t do the killing yourself.

notes.text: 1,000 points You’re the equivalent of a brick, but without superpowers. Instead, your enhanced strength and toughness come from technology: a suit of armor that senses, imitates, and amplifies your movements. This is far enough beyond existing technology for the suit’s abilities to be bought as advantages with gadget limitations. It’s assumed that you built it yourself, and maintain it as needed.
